messages: b844a0a98f81c321afe1d38ae37f3c28 (11:43): channel #whatwg
25812bf456959aa5f28dc570f341a3ba (11:43): is 'WHATWG (HTML5) -- http://www.whatwg.org/ -- Logs: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/ -- Please leave your sense of logic at the door, thanks!'
5d5b78699e57104f2fa03bbdf7b9197b (11:43): by gsnedders on Tue Dec 18 21:41:19
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:43): I got a huge email, so Mail.app has been busy with one message all morning
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:44): so I can't be distracted by the RDFa thread for a while still...
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:44): Well, unless you're a glutton for punishment... :)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: great opportunity to get acctual work done :)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:45): "We can't use classes because people might try to dereference them. Instead we use namespace URLs, which magically always can be dereferenced."
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:45): these "Digital Bazaar" people sure write a lot
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): some of the needs of these rdfa people are things we should probably address
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): i'm just not sure any of them actually require spec changes
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:46): "Only URIs are ever unique. A classname with all the same characters as a URI will magically cause collisions."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:46): but i'll get back to rdfa once i've dealt with the workers and parsing feedback
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:46): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I have a solution for that one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:47): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: defining that class names that contain a colon MUST be IRIs
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:47): "We know squat about why namespaces are bad."
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: That doesn't stop collisions, though. Anyone's free to type whatever they want

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:48): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I was going to ask how they plan to keep URIs both unique and dereferencable since it sems to me that atm having one property means that you cannot ensure the other, even assuming good faith
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:48): There is no URI police that will come to your house and stop you
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:48): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: the same holds true for RDFa property attribute
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:49): Dereferenceable => URLs, right? and URLs imply DNS which has finite-time registrations.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:50): (in practice there are shorter term problems)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:50): They work around that with purl et.al.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:50): the long term problems are somewhat annoying too; if I die, will I need to set up a fund to keep annevankesteren.nl alive?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: So they basically build a second centralised registry
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:51): who is the purl overlord?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (11:51): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Ssh, it's impolite to point out elephants
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): In which case why bother putting http://purl.org at the front of everything
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:51): Why not just have unique human-readable prefixes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:52): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: well, purl.org NS uris depend on 3 centralized registries that are independent, so it's decentralized in that sense

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: what are the 3 independent registries? Presumably there is only one body handling out purl.org uris, so purl.org, not dns becomes the bottleneck in that case
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:54): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: purl.org itself (for its subspace), domain registry and the URI scheme registry
7337f93f7cad4c6cc0e77851c8a12248 (11:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: can't remember what I wanted to ask you about now.. will ping you if/when I remember
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I think that's just three things that could go wrong, not three layers of redundancy
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:55): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yes. but the three things are distributed :-)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:56): "distributed modes of failiure" doesn't sound that confidence inspiring :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:00): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: i don't think b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 is defending RDFa :-)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:01): RDF sounds very nice in theory though, still

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e's question was interesting, though. Would they actually endorse a situation where an entire vocabulary becomes unusable because someone takes their webpage down?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:02): I'd love to have a unified parsing model for microformats but without namespaces, CURIEs or overlong identifiers
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:02): my guess is that two to four letter prefixes disambiguate enough
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:02): IIRC, in the wikimedia commons SVG analysis, the namespace prefix collisions were:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:03): 1) autogenerated ns1
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:03): 2) cc changing its URI
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:03): 3) Adobe and Microsoft claiming the same one-letter prefix
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:04): so unified parsing means you can easily create a graph out of some nodes?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:04): i love that the response to 2) is "but because you can dereference it, it's ok! we can map them to each other!"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:04): because after that you will still have to perform format specific operations, which are probably more complicated than the parsing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:05): the syntax introduces a problem that is solved by the syntax, i love it
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:05): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I'd settle for a tree
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:05): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: if you end up with a triple-store, you can use standard tools to do inference

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:06): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: which supports things like mapping vocabularies to each other, or saying that anything that is a car is also a four-wheeled object
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:06): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: so even if your tool originally only knew about wheels, it could work out that each car implied four weels
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:06): yeah, but you still need to create the "export to Vcard" function
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:06): yeah well, i'm not sure i understand what the ui would really be
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:07): I don't think it solves that part (although some people suggest it does)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: one semweb enthusiast I used to have lunches with occasionally at least used to advocate a UI like NakedObjects
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:07): http://www.nakedobjects.org/home/index.shtml
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:08): (I don't think that makes a good UI, though.)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:09): fails to find Havoc Pennington's essay that identifies "I can generate the UI" as a passing phase
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:10): here it is: http://www106.pair.com/rhp/free-software-ui.html
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Yeah, every time I hear about RDFa I think of that...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:15): A library that does everything your applications need except for generating the UI still sounds like a quite useful thing to have
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:16): The other question I didn't ask about RDFa is why it will work when rel="home", "next" etc. have effectively failed
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:17): What does "failed" mean?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:18): has never noticed them causing harm, and has found them to be useful when he uses them on his own pages
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:18): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: They aren't used that much and IIRC aren't supported by default in 99% of browsers
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:19): In fact you even have to turn on support in Opera I think
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:19): They're on by default in Opera
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:19): or at least the 'next' one is

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:21): I think ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 was right that the problem is that because they are only used for 1 in n pages people don't learn to look in the chrome for functions related to intra-site navigation

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:21): (e.g. if I go to http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/fallback.multiple.html and use a 'forward' shortcut (ctrl+right, right-click-and-drag-rightwards, etc) then it goes to the next page)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): feed autodiscovery got UI
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:22): rel=next is different from the rest
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (12:23): That never occurred to me before -- how did feed autodiscovery succeed while rel= mostly failed?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: You're right of course.
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (12:24): or I should say, <link rel= failed -- <a rel= is useful, because you're not relying on browsers to do anything special
ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2 (12:24): it's an optional extra, like microformat detection
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:25): http://ajaxian.com/archives/ubiquity-quicksilver-of-the-firefox-browser could benefit from RDFa annotated data
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (12:25): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: You can also just press space on that page. It scrolls down, and when it can't scroll anymore, it goes to the next page.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:25): (I think I've seen Opera's next-page thing working far more often when it automatically determines an ordered list from Apache directory indexes and lets you jump from one file straight to the next in the directory, rather than from explicit rel=nexts)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:30): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6: that feature is awesome. (which is why I think rel=next is not like the rest)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:31): I guess feed discovery progressed for on-page links to not relying on-page links.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:31): *from on-page
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:31): maybe if <a rel="next" and associated UI became commonplace
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:31): rel=next also causes a page to be prefetched in Firefox
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:31): then <link rel="next" would work too
da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6 (12:31): <link rel='next'> is a pain, though. <a rel='next'> would be much nicer.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:31): ac35308fff7abada50397bb69d5658e2: I would hazard a guess that it has something to do with the fact that you can predict which sites have feeds and the fact that they used the same icon that people had got used to on-page offpage
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:31): (similar to rel=prefetch)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (12:32): da5121879fff54b08b69ec54d9ac2bf6: are feed icons nicer than feed autodiscovery?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:38): Does anyone know how Firefox JIT compares with WebKit Squirrelfish?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:40): seems to be faster
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:41): Apparently it wins on SunSpider
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:41): right
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:42): Meanwhile, the IE team has a blog post saying that JScript performance isn't that important really
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:44): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: even though IE seems to need the most JS libraries between it and the app programmer :-)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:44): likes how http://home.kairo.at/blog/2008-08/how_fast_is_tracemonkey_in_real_world measures "stuff a real application might use" by calculating Mandelbrot fractals
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:45): wishes Apple shipped GNU versions of basic Unix tools
